thread.title: Indian Football Team draws inspiration from previous contest
thread.title_full: Indian Football Team draws inspiration from previous contest

author: muscatdaily@apexmedia.co.om (Muscat Daily News)
title: Indian Football Team draws inspiration from previous contest
text:
Follow us on Indian Football Team draws inspiration from previous contest Indian players at a training session with coach Stephen Constantine at the SQSC on Sunday (Muscat Daily) Muscat Daily staff writer October 13, 2015 
The visiting Indian team hopes to take lessons from its previous match against Oman, on June 11 at home in Bengaluru, when it fought hard in a 1-2 loss. 
Having suffered defeats in all its games so far in the joint qualifiers for the 2018 World Cup and the 2019 Asian Cup, India coach Stephen Constantine has his task cut out when his players meet hosts Oman on Tuesday. 
“It is going to be a difficult match, but we will try to give our best,” said the Englishman, who has been at the helm of the team for seven months. 
L-R: Stephen Constantine, Sunil Chhetri and an Oman Football Association official at Monday’s press meet 
Constantine said, “Oman is the most underrated team, but it has a good coach in Paul Le Guen, who has been with the side for the past four years. They know how to play football.” 
Indian captain Sunil Chhetri recalled the tight contest in the June 11 face-off, saying, “We had put up a good performance against Oman at home. I am sure the boys will take confidence from that game. 
“No doubt, we were playing at home and now we are playing away. It is a different game altogether when you play away as we have lost two away games. We will try our best to garner points tomorrow. We definitely want to change the trend.” 
The Indians lost a day of training due to their late arrival from Ashgabat, Turkmenistan owing to a flight delay caused by bad weather. 
India lost 1-2 at Ashbagat, but Chhetri sounded upbeat on Monday, saying, “We aim to keep all the negatives away and hope to put up a good fight.” 
Constantine said that despite the team not having a single point in the group stage so far, ‘motivation is not a problem ever for the players’. 
“Playing for the national team is a big motivation for the players. The desire of representing your country is always there,” he said. 
The India coach said that the delay in arrival in Muscat was not the best way to prepare for a World Cup qualifier. “But it is what it is and we have to move on,” he said. 
The Englishman, who is going through a second spell as India coach, said, “Oman has some very good players and over the years they have produced consistent results. 
“The draw against Iran was no surprise for me. We have respect for Oman, but we are here to play and we will fight. We didn’t come here to lose. We don’t go anywhere to lose.” 
‘Qualification to Asian Cup is still possible’ Constantine said that though India is realistically not in the race for a World Cup berth, the joint qualifiers offer a chance to bag a spot in the prestigious Asian Cup. 
“The group stage was always a two-horse race between Iran and Oman for the World Cup, but we will try to qualify for the Asian Cup and we can advance if we win our games against Guam [on November 12] and Turkmenistan at home [on March 29, 2016],” he said. 
Building a team for the future Constantine said that he is building a team for the future and the fact that he has tried out 16 new players underlines that strategy. 
“Over the past seven games, I have had 16 new players. We are in the early stages and it is important to give chances to fresh blood,” said Constantine. “It’s understandable that people want instant success, but you can't have that. It will take time.” Similar content
